author: @TravisTraps
text: This is so wild Luke....you basically shared my personal learning roadmap. Started my DA journey in March 2021. Started with Google DA cert, then moved on to UC-Davis SQL Training, then the UC-Davis Tableau specialization. Already had previous working knowledge of Excel. I was able to use these courses to increase my pay by over 50% by quitting teaching and becoming a data analyst. Thank you for the recommendations on what are the best Python courses though, that is my next target. Suppose I can benefit from the Excel course too. Thank you for sharing these. Crazy to see how my own personal journey matched this video. Wish I had this video when I started, I had to compare and contrast on these courses on my own.

author: @rachellerachelle71
text: Thanks Luke for sharing and making this videos for us newbies! I am new to the idea of becoming a Data Analyst. My dear friend just recently landed a entry-level position with Accenture, after being a (paid) intern for a year. He was making 48K with no prior experience and no degree; only having a certificate from the General Assembly bootcamp. Now, in his current position, of just one year, he is making more than 75K in Chicago! He loves his job and works remotely, 90% of the time. He learned CSS, HTML, JavaScript, jQuery, React, MongoDB, Express, Ruby, Ruby on Rails and Fullstack applications. He believes I have the aptitude for this field.  However, I know he's tech savvy and me, not so much...he's 41 and I am 52. We both have had major struggles in life trying to find out what we want to do in our careers. We both have had jobs in car sales/finance, dance and health industries and various odd jobs. I recently became a Flight Attendant, love the free flying benefits but hate having to be away from home so much...I'm so torn. I don't know if my brain is capable of retaining all the vast, complex information and/or if I'm talented enough for this ever changing, competitive industry.

author: @noor_51
text: Incredible stuff here Sir. I would encourage anyone watching to follow these tips in becoming a Data Analyst. Just ensure that you get some credible certifications to prove your competence. This will make it very easy to get recognized among the crowd. There are tons of them, some are even free like the Alteryx certification. I can help guide anyone to pass the Alteryx exams. I am already certified. Before all these, I graduated with my first degree in Mathematics. However, it was very tough finding a job with that degree. I then started learning Data Analytics on YouTube and acquired intermediate competence in using various software like Excel, SQL, Tableau, and Power BI. Despite having these skills, it was still very challenging to land my first job because I didn't have the credentials to justify my skills. So I resorted to online freelancing while building my professional network. It was then that an idea struck me to seek certification that could enable me prove my competence in the said areas. However, another major obstacle was that majority of the certifications like Tableau, Power Bi, and Oracle were a bit expensive for me since I didn't have a job yet. So I learnt of Alteryx free certification and aced it https://www.dropbox.com/s/9imtpea345s166h/Alteryx%20Cert.jpg?dl=0. It became a good starting point for me and later on I was able to raise funds and register for the paid certifications. I am glad and appreciative for the progress I have made ever since.

author: @nicholasg9804
text: very few people seem to have finished the google data analytics certs. people were cheating so google starting adding new questions and randomizing them. as you go on to the later courses you will see how few people actually moved on to the later courses. people start, finishing the first class, and realize its a LOT more work then they thought it would be.   it is a lot of work. but its still hella good.   its not nearly as much work as my BA from a top school... but its like maybe one quarter of hard work. I mean, there is so much to understand, so dont rush it. take your time. if you get the cert, but dont have the skills, it does even make sense.   I just graduated college,  now finishing the cert and then I will look for work... I want to find remote work, I live in the  united states, california.   kinda scared about finishing my first job after college

author: @semin2video
text: A warning for those who intend to take the R course mentioned in the video: this course is not for those without any experience with R. Even if you have some experience with R this R course by JHU is still unreasonably difficult. Particularly the assignments are beyond the scope of the lecture. My recommendation is go get some good books on R and relevant tools (for example, R for Data Science) and other more decent course(s) on R.

Crazy to see how my own personal journey matched this video. Wish I had this video when I started, I had to compare and contrast on these courses on my own.

author: @GalaxyTracker
text: Hi Luke. I am a recent subscriber. I would like to ask your opinion on some path choices. My field is environmental engineering and I am interested in learning data analysis in order to build my CV,  maybe land a job in research and get accepted into a Masters for uni. I need data analysis for working with large data structures for projects and studies. I realized, writing my thesis, that, if I knew Python, I would easily be able to work with my dataset, and would save weeks off my project. So, now, I started with "Python for Everybody" in Coursera, which teaches you Python to work with data structures, etc. I plan to go for the Google certificate after this. My plan is to finish them both in the next 9 months. In short, I don't need the data analysis certificate as a main requirement for the job, but more as a means to have more skills in search for a job in research fields and for an application for a Masters. I have some programming background, so, they seem easy, so far. Have you got any other recommendations? Thank you in advance and keep up the good work!
